moves.1. e4 c5: Black open with the Sicilian Defense.
moves.2. e5 f6 3. Nf3 fxe5 4. Nxe5 d6 5. Nc4 b: I wish I knew what my opponent was thinking here, moving the Knight instead of developing.
moves.7... e6 8. Nf4 Nf6 9. Qe2 Qe7 10. f3 e5: This is where I saw an opportunity to come ahead in captured pieces.
moves.12. Nb4 a5 13. Nd5: I would have played 13. Nd3 instead to at least win a pawn.
moves.17. Na3: But white wisely defends against the fork.
moves.17... Bd7 18. Qg3 Bf5: Trying to open the fork again.
moves.22... Nxa2+ 23. Kb1 Ncb4 24. Nxb5: White takes the free pawn, leaving Nxc2 defended only by the king.
moves.25. cxb3 c2+ 26. Kb2 cxd1=Q: Regain the queen lost in 25. cxb3
moves.27. Qf2 a4 28. Nc7+: White forks the black King and Rook.
moves.30. Ka1 Nc2+: This forces 31. Qxc2 Qxc2 and black trades a Knight for a Queen.
moves.33. Nb6+ Kc6 34. Nc4 e4+ 35. d4: White could also have palyed 35. Bf6 or 35. Ne5, but all variations lead to check each time.
